results.title: A Rookie airman's story
results.brief_description: Cliff’s father was a fisherman, so he knew about boats. After joining the airforce in 1942 he would spend the majority of his service running missions on boats. Lucky he didn’t tell them he couldn’t swim.
results.description: Cliff’s father was a fisherman, so he knew about boats. After joining the airforce in 1942 he would spend the majority of his service running missions on boats. Lucky he didn’t tell them he couldn’t swim.

results.title: On the road again
results.creator_credit: Bill Medlyn, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 1942, Bill joined the army, taking his brothers place who returned home to work on the farm. Bill worked in many capacities as a driver and instructor. Having a severe driving accident on a mission, Bill landed in hospital for three months with a fractured spine. Making a good recovery, he was able to return to service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Medlyn, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Airman at sea
results.brief_description: As Keith flew from Townsville to Milne Bay in Papua New Guinea, he wondered if he would ever see the shores of Australia again. Suffering from dengue fever, Keith battled illness the whole time. He made it back when the war ended and would go on to serve in the RAFF for 20 years.

results.title: Land and sea
results.creator_credit: Keith Payne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Keith Payne had a terrible acne problem when he was a youngster but it only got worse when he was deployed into the tropics. Unfortunately for Payne, his attempts to sign up to volunteer in Japan were shot down when the doctors looked at his acne and sent him home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Payne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: In my blood
results.creator_credit: Jack Bell, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Serving in Libya , Jack was captured and became a POW. Almost dying from injures , he would spend over 3 months in prisoner camps in Europe. Today he still remember his mates who didn’t make it and the doctor who who saved his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Bell, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Cook's tour
results.creator_credit: Bryan Chipperfield, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Bryan Chipperfield saw no action during his service in the air force. Posted to Calgary in Canada, Chipperfield was able to enjoy skiing, boating and playing sports. Keeping up to date with the war through reading the paper, he knew he may be asked to ‘play his part’ at any time.

Read by fellow veteran Bill Medlyn for Bryan Chipperfield

results.title: A Naive country kid
results.brief_description:
At 17 Greg joined the air force and his role would be to give the aircraft the best chance of surviving a crash. Two years after joining up, Greg was sent to Thailand and one particular aircraft rescue would change his outlook on life forever.
Called out to an aircraft crash to help the Americans contain a huge fire, the Aussies were unaware where the aircraft had come from. After the flames were put out, Greg would realise this was a Thai plane that he had flown on many times. The memory of this day would stay with him all his life.

results.title: An interview with Patrick Bourke
results.brief_description: Patrick Bourke was 16 when he grew onions with his father. Wanting to get out of this, he decided to join the navy. After convincing his father, he started work on his first ship H.M.A.S Adele, sighting subs and signalling wherever he was. Patrick retells some of his tales out at sea.

results.title: John Miles: drafted Vietnam
results.brief_description: John Miles recalls the 29th of September 1965 as the date that he commenced his National Service. While he was away, the political climate changed dramatically in Australia. Miles remembers his experience of the Vietnam War and his struggles once home in Australia. Miles’ treatment on return to Australia initially made left him feeling bitter, but a trip back to Vietnam was crucial to his personal transformation and healing.
results.description: John Miles recalls the 29th of September 1965 as the date that he commenced his National Service. While he was away, the political climate changed dramatically in Australia. Miles remembers his experience of the Vietnam War and his struggles once home in Australia. Miles’ treatment on return to Australia initially made left him feeling bitter, but a trip back to Vietnam was crucial to his personal transformation and healing.

results.title: An interview with Cyril Sayles
results.brief_description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.
results.description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.
description_for_label: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.
